     <p>
      This is a list of
      <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">
       video games
      </a>
      that have sold or shipped at least one million copies on a single platform (unless otherwise noted).
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="All_platforms">
       All platforms
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Multi-platform">
       Multi-platform
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="wikitable sortable">
      <caption>
       Games across all platforms that have sold at least 15 million copies, across multiple platforms
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-1">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         n 1
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>

       </th>
       <th scope="col">
        System(s)
       </th>
       <th data-sort-type="number" scope="col">
        Copies sold /
        <br/>
        Paid downloads
       </th>
      </tr>

      <span class="mw-headline" id="Single-platform">

      </span>

     <table class="wikitable sortable">

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Consoles">
       Consoles
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Bundled_games">
       Bundled games
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="wikitable sortable">
      <caption>
       Games that were bundled for a significant portion of their shelf life and have sold or shipped at least ten million copies
      </caption>

       <th>

        Copies sold

        </sup>

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Xbox_360">
       Xbox 360
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_Xbox_360_video_games" title="List of best-selling Xbox 360 video games">
       List of best-selling Xbox 360 video games
      </a>
     </div>
     <table class="vertical-navbox" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;padding:0em; line-height:normal; font-size:100%; border-spacing:2px 0px;">
      <tr>
       <td style="padding:0.4em 0">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vg_icon.svg">
         <img alt="Vg icon.svg" data-file-height="42" data-file-width="56" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Vg_icon.svg/150px-Vg_icon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Vg_icon.svg/225px-Vg_icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Vg_icon.svg/300px-Vg_icon.svg.png 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>

       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gamepad.svg">
        <img alt="Gamepad.svg" data-file-height="128" data-file-width="128" height="36" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Gamepad.svg/36px-Gamepad.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Gamepad.svg/54px-Gamepad.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/be/Gamepad.svg/72px-Gamepad.svg.png 2x" width="36"/>
       </a>
       <i>
        This
        <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">
         video game
        </a>
        -related list is an
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Lists#Incomplete_lists" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Lists">
         incomplete list
        </a>
        , which may never be able to satisfy particular standards for completeness. You can help by
        <span class="noprint plainlinks">
         <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_PC_games&amp;action=edit">
          expanding
         </a>
        </span>
       </i>
       it with
       <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources">
        reliably sourced
       </a>
       entries.
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <p>
      This is a list of
      <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">
       Xbox 360
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">
       video games
      </a>
      that have sold or shipped at least one million copies, sorted in order of copies sold. Some games may have also been released on platforms other than the Xbox 360, in which case only the sales figures from the Xbox 360 versions are counted. There are also some games not listed that were included in bundle packs with the Kinect.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tnone">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3115" data-file-width="3700" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png/220px-Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png/330px-Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png/440px-Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Xbox-360-Consoles-Infobox.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">
         Xbox 360
        </a>
        Elite and Xbox 360 S consoles.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>

       <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Kinect">
        <b>

          ^
         </a>

       <b>
        a:
       </b>
       As of February 12, 2013, the
       <a href="/wiki/Kinect" title="Kinect">
        Kinect
       </a>
       sensor has sold 24 million units,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bgr_67-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-bgr-67">
         <span>

         </span>

         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       each of which is bundled with a copy of
       <i>
        Kinect Adventures
       </i>
       .
      </li>

       <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Gears">

          ^
         </a>

       </b>

       <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_XBLA">

          ^
         </a>

       </b>
       <a href="/wiki/Xbox_Live_Arcade" title="Xbox Live Arcade">
        Xbox Live Arcade
       </a>
       game
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      Total Xbox 360 games sold as of December 2009: 353.8 million.

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Nintendo">
       Nintendo
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Total games Nintendo has sold as of March 31, 2014: 4.22 billion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nintendosales_79-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nintendosales-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Super_Nintendo_Entertainment_System">

      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">

       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2840" data-file-width="5472" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg/220px-SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg/330px-SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg/440px-SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg 2x" width="220"/>

        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SNES-Mod1-Console-Set.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>

      </div>
     </div>

        <a href="/wiki/Ubisoft" title="Ubisoft">
         Ubisoft
        </a>

     </table>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_periph">
        <b>
         <a href="#ref_periph">
          ^
         </a>
        </b>
       </span>
       <b>
        a:
       </b>
       Bundled with a popular accessory (e.g. additional Wii-mote, MotionPlus, Wii Zapper, Wii Wheel).
      </li>
      <li>
       <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_console">
        <b>
         <a href="#ref_console">
          ^
         </a>
        </b>
       </span>
       <b>
        b:
       </b>
       Bundled with a version of the console. The white console was commonly bundled with
       <i>
        Wii Sports
       </i>
       at launch; since the release of MotionPlus, the Wii Sports bundle with either the white or black console also includes
       <i>
        Wii Sports Resort
       </i>
       . In addition, since the launch of the corresponding games, the white console has been commonly bundled with
       <i>
        Mario Kart Wii
       </i>
       (and the Wii Wheel), and the black console has been commonly bundled with
       <i>
        New Super Mario Bros. Wii
       </i>
       .
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      Total Wii games sold as of March 31, 2014: 895.22 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nintendosales_79-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-nintendosales-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Total
      <a href="/wiki/Virtual_Console" title="Virtual Console">
       Virtual Console
      </a>
      games sold as of December 31, 2007: over 10 million
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        141
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Wii_U">
       Wii U
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wii_U_Console_and_Gamepad.jpg">

       Nintendo Wii U games which have sold or shipped at least one million copies [

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Game_Boy_and_Game_Boy_Color">
       Game Boy and Game Boy Color
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Game-Boy-Original.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="1500" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Game-Boy-Original.jpg/150px-Game-Boy-Original.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Game-Boy-Original.jpg/225px-Game-Boy-Original.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Game-Boy-Original.jpg/300px-Game-Boy-Original.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Game-Boy-Original.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Original Game Boy
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_Game_Boy_video_games" title="List of best-selling Game Boy video games">
       List of best-selling Game Boy video games
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:228px;max-width:228px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:115px;max-width:115px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Game-Boy-Original.jpg">
          <img alt="Game Boy" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="1500" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Game-Boy-Original.jpg/113px-Game-Boy-Original.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Game-Boy-Original.jpg/170px-Game-Boy-Original.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Game-Boy-Original.jpg/226px-Game-Boy-Original.jpg 2x" width="113"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:109px;max-width:109px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Game-Boy-Color-Purple.png">
          <img alt="Game Boy Color" data-file-height="2436" data-file-width="1440" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Game-Boy-Color-Purple.png/107px-Game-Boy-Color-Purple.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Game-Boy-Color-Purple.png/161px-Game-Boy-Color-Purple.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Game-Boy-Color-Purple.png/214px-Game-Boy-Color-Purple.png 2x" width="107"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Game_Boy_Advance">
       Game Boy Advance
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2640" data-file-width="3260" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg/220px-Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg/330px-Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg/440px-Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gameboy-Advance-SP-Mk2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Game Boy Advance SP
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>

      Main article:

      </a>

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Nintendo_DS">

        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1800" data-file-width="2400" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Nintendo-DS-Lite-w-stylus.png/220px-Nintendo-DS-Lite-w-stylus.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Nintendo-DS-Lite-w-stylus.png/330px-Nintendo-DS-Lite-w-stylus.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Nintendo-DS-Lite-w-stylus.png/440px-Nintendo-DS-Lite-w-stylus.png 2x" width="220"/>

       </td>

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Nintendo_3DS">

     <div class="thumb tright">

       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nintendo-3DS-AquaOpen.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2080" data-file-width="2300" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Nintendo-3DS-AquaOpen.png/220px-Nintendo-3DS-AquaOpen.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Nintendo-3DS-AquaOpen.png/330px-Nintendo-3DS-AquaOpen.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Nintendo-3DS-AquaOpen.png/440px-Nintendo-3DS-AquaOpen.png 2x" width="220"/>

        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2960" data-file-width="5760" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Sega-Genesis-Mk2-6button.jpg/220px-Sega-Genesis-Mk2-6button.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Sega-Genesis-Mk2-6button.jpg/330px-Sega-Genesis-Mk2-6button.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Sega-Genesis-Mk2-6button.jpg/440px-Sega-Genesis-Mk2-6button.jpg 2x" width="220"/>

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="PlayStation_2">
       PlayStation 2
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PS2-Versions.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2480" data-file-width="2800" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/PS2-Versions.jpg/220px-PS2-Versions.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/PS2-Versions.jpg/330px-PS2-Versions.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/PS2-Versions.jpg/440px-PS2-Versions.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PS2-Versions.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Original (left) and slim (right)
        <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_2" title="PlayStation 2">
         PlayStation 2
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>

      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_PlayStation_2_video_games" title="List of best-selling PlayStation 2 video games">
       List of best-selling PlayStation 2 video games
      </a>
     </div>

     <p>
      Total PlayStation 2 games
      <i>
       shipped
      </i>
      as of March 31, 2007: 1.24 billion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        228
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Total PlayStation 2 games
      <i>
       sold
      </i>
      between April 1, 2007 and March 31, 2012: 297.5 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
       <a href="#cite_note-231">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        229
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Note that since the former figure refers to shipments and the latter refers to sales, there may be some overlap between the two figures.
     </p>

     <div class="thumb tright">

       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PlayStation-Vita-1101-FL.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="5310" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/PlayStation-Vita-1101-FL.jpg/220px-PlayStation-Vita-1101-FL.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/PlayStation-Vita-1101-FL.jpg/330px-PlayStation-Vita-1101-FL.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/PlayStation-Vita-1101-FL.jpg/440px-PlayStation-Vita-1101-FL.jpg 2x" width="220"/>

       <td>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Call_of_Duty:_Black_Ops:_Declassified" title="Call of Duty: Black Ops: Declassified">
          Call of Duty: Black Ops: Declassified
         </a>
        </i>
       </td>
       <td>
        1.22 million
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">

            citation needed
           </span>
          </a>
         </i>
         ]
        </sup>

      </tr>

       <td>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/LittleBigPlanet_PS_Vita" title="LittleBigPlanet PS Vita">
          LittleBigPlanet PS Vita
         </a>
        </i>
       </td>
       <td>
        1.09 million
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">

         </i>
         ]
        </sup>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      Total PlayStation Vita games sold as of June 24, 2015: 38.36 million.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="PC">
       PC
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_PC_games" title="List of best-selling PC games">
       List of best-selling PC games
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/PC_game" title="PC game">
       PC games
      </a>
      for
      <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">
       Microsoft Windows
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mac_OS_X" title="Mac OS X">
       Mac OS X
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Linux" title="Linux">
       Linux
      </a>
      platforms that have sold or shipped at least
      <i>
       five
      </i>
      million copies. Expansion packs are not used in calculation of the sales figure for the original game (with the exception of
      <i>
       StarCraft
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       Guild Wars
      </i>
      ). Sales from digital distribution stores (such as
      <a href="/wiki/Steam_(software)" title="Steam (software)">
       Steam
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Direct2Drive" title="Direct2Drive">
       Direct2Drive
      </a>
      ) are not generally included since these figures are not generally released to the public, as well as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/VGChartz" title="VGChartz">
       VGChartz
      </a>
      and similar publications being unable to accurately track these sales.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
         <span title="Many of the games in this list are only available on e.g. Steam/Origin, making this statement incorrect. If this is a recommendation about sources of information, it would be better placed on the List of best-selling PC games article. (June 2015)">
          clarification needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:85%;">
      <caption>
       PC games for
       <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">
        Microsoft Windows
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mac_OS_X" title="Mac OS X">
        Mac OS X
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Linux" title="Linux">
        Linux
       </a>
       platforms that have sold or shipped at least five million copies [
       <span class="noprint plainlinks">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_PC_games&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1">
         edit
        </a>
       </span>
       ]
      </caption>
      <tr>
       <th style="width:15%;">

       </th>

        Total copies sold
       </th>
       <th style="width:20%;">

       <th style="width:10%;">
        Franchise

       <th style="width:10%;">
        Release date

       <th style="width:10%;">
        Genre
       </th>
       <th style="width:10%;">
        Developer
       </th>
       <th style="width:10%;">
        Publisher
       </th>
      </tr>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Arcade">
       Arcade
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_arcade_games" title="List of highest-grossing arcade games">
       List of highest-grossing arcade games
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Golden_age_of_arcade_video_games" title="Golden age of arcade video games">
       Golden age of arcade video games
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      This list includes
      <a href="/wiki/Arcade_game" title="Arcade game">
       arcade games
      </a>
      that have sold at least 10,000 or more
      <a href="/wiki/Video_game_arcade_cabinet" title="Video game arcade cabinet">
       arcade hardware
      </a>
      units.
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable sortable">
      <tr>
       <th>
        Title
       </th>

        Copies sold
       </th>
      </tr>

      <ol class="references">
       <li id="cite_note-1">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-1">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         All sale figures for the all platforms lists are taken from the other lists unless otherwise noted.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-Minecraft_release-6">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-Minecraft_release_6-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-Minecraft_release_6-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Although
         <i>
          Minecraft
         </i>
         was first publicly available on 17 May 2009,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4">
          <a href="#cite_note-4">
           <span>
            [
           </span>
           3
           <span>
            ]
           </span>
          </a>
         </sup>
         and the 1.0 version on 18 November 2011, the first version of
         <i>
          Minecraft
         </i>
         which required a paid account was first publicly available on 23 December 2009,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5">
          <a href="#cite_note-5">
           <span>
            [
           </span>
           4
           <span>
            ]
           </span>
          </a>
         </sup>
         therefore it started accumulating sales on that year.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-280">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-280">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Subscribers are not the same as sales; many Asian markets use a different business model that does not involve retail copies. As such subscriber figures do not equate to sales figures.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-282">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-282">

          </a>

        <span class="reference-text">

         <i>
          World of Warcraft
         </i>
         annual pass offer.

       <li id="cite_note-27">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-27">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.bethblog.com/2013/06/10/e3-2013-eso-arriving-on-playstation-4-xbox-one/" rel="nofollow">
           "E3 2013: ESO Arriving on PlayStation 4, Xbox One!"
          </a>
          . Bethesda Softworks. June 10, 2013
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            November 27,
           </span>
           2013
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           As the follow-up to the 2002 Role-Playing Game of the Year,
           <i>
            The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind
           </i>
           , and the 2006 Game of the Year,
           <i>
            The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion
           </i>
           ,
           <i>
            Skyrim
           </i>
           earned hundreds of Game of the Year awards and has sold over 20 million copies.
          </q>

           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.atitle=The+video+games+boom+has+yet+to+come&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.au=Hutcheon%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Hutcheon&amp;rft.date=7+June+1983&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.google.com%2Fnewspapers%3Fid%3DfC5VAAAAIBAJ%26sjid%3DnpQDAAAAIBAJ%26pg%3D4131%2C3188851&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Age&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">

          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

         <span class="citation news">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aufirst=Darren&amp;rft.aulast=Waters&amp;rft.au=Waters%2C+Darren&amp;rft.btitle=Molyneux+driven+by+past+failure&amp;rft.date=2008-02-25&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F2%2Fhi%2Ftechnology%2F7262202.stm&amp;rft.pub=BBC+News&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

          </span>
          .
         </span>

       <li id="cite_note-guinness_2009-219">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-guinness_2009_219-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation book">
          <i>
           Guinness World Records 2009 Gamer's Edition
          </i>
          . pp.108109.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1904994458" title="Special:BookSources/1904994458">
           1904994458
          </a>
          .
          <q>
           <i>
            GTA: San Andreas
           </i>
           is the best-selling PlayStation 2 game of all time, with a massive 17.33 million copies sold.
          </q>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aulast=Spencer&amp;rft.au=Spencer&amp;rft.btitle=E3+2006+Hidden+gems+to+watch+out+for&amp;rft.date=2006-05-08&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.siliconera.com%2F2006%2F05%2F08%2Fe3-2006-hidden-gems-to-watch-out-for%2F&amp;rft.pub=Siliconera&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Podolsky&amp;rft.au=Podolsky%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.btitle=%27Guitar+Hero+Mobile%27+a+Smashing+Success&amp;rft.date=2008-06-13&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pcmag.com%2Farticle2%2F0%2C2817%2C2320042%2C00.asp&amp;rft.pub=%27%27PC+Magazine%27%27&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-310">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-310">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation pressrelease">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.gamershell.com/companies/hudson/393495.html" rel="nofollow">
           "Hudson Entertainment Brings Bomberman Land Series to Mobile Phones"
          </a>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.btitle=Hudson+Entertainment+Brings+Bomberman+Land+Series+to+Mobile+Phones&amp;rft.date=2008-01-25&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gamershell.com%2Fcompanies%2Fhudson%2F393495.html&amp;rft.pub=Hudson+Soft&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-311">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-311">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation book">
          <a href="/wiki/John_Kao" title="John Kao">
           Kao, John J.
          </a>
          (1989).
          <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=P-MJAQAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            Entrepreneurship, creativity &amp; organization: text, cases &amp; readings
           </i>
          </a>
          . Englewood Cliffs, NJ:
          <a href="/wiki/Prentice_Hall" title="Prentice Hall">
           Prentice Hall
          </a>
          . p.45.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-13-283011-6" title="Special:BookSources/0-13-283011-6">
           0-13-283011-6
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            12 February
           </span>
           2012
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           Estimates counted 7 billion coins that by 1982 had been inserted into some 400,000 Pac Man machines worldwide, equal to one game of Pac Man for every person on earth. US domestic revenues from games and licensing of the Pac Man image for T-shirts, pop songs, to wastepaper baskets, etc. exceeded $1 billion.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aufirst=John+J.&amp;rft.au=Kao%2C+John+J.&amp;rft.aulast=Kao&amp;rft.btitle=Entrepreneurship%2C+creativity+%26+organization%3A+text%2C+cases+%26+readings&amp;rft.date=1989&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DP-MJAQAAMAAJ&amp;rft.isbn=0-13-283011-6&amp;rft.pages=45&amp;rft.place=Englewood+Cliffs%2C+NJ&amp;rft.pub=Prentice+Hall&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-312">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-312">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation" id="CITEREFJiji_Gaho_Sha.2C_inc.2003">
          Jiji Gaho Sha, inc. (2003),
          <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CTRWAAAAYAAJ" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            Asia Pacific perspectives, Japan
           </i>
          </a>
          <b>
           1
          </b>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/University_of_Virginia" title="University of Virginia">
           University of Virginia
          </a>
          , p.57
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           , retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2011-04-09
           </span>
          </span>
          ,
          <q>
           At that time, a game for use in entertainment arcades was considered a hit if it sold 1000 units; sales of Space Invaders topped 300,000 units in Japan and 60,000 units overseas.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.au=Jiji+Gaho+Sha%2C+inc.&amp;rft.aulast=Jiji+Gaho+Sha%2C+inc.&amp;rft.btitle=Asia+Pacific+perspectives%2C+Japan&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DCTRWAAAAYAAJ&amp;rft.pages=57&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Virginia&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.volume=1">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-dk_sales-314">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-dk_sales_314-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-dk_sales_314-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <i>
          Donkey Kong
         </i>
         sales:
        </span>
        <ul>
         <li>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Japan: 65,000 of
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Donkey_Kong_(video_game)" title="Donkey Kong (video game)">
             Donkey Kong
            </a>
           </i>
          </span>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="reference-text">
             <span class="citation book">
              Brian Ashcraft; with Jean Snow.; forewords by Kevin Williams; Crecente, Brian (2008).
              <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=DH03T87uGYbp8QO-rtHMAg&amp;id=wX8kAQAAIAAJ&amp;dq=" rel="nofollow">
               "sixty-five+thousand"
               <i>
                Arcade Mania: The Turbo-charged World of Japan's Game Centers
               </i>
              </a>
              (1st ed. ed.). Tokyo:
              <a href="/wiki/Kodansha" title="Kodansha">
               Kodansha International
              </a>
              .
              <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
               ISBN
              </a>
              <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/4-7700-3078-9" title="Special:BookSources/4-7700-3078-9">
               4-7700-3078-9
              </a>
              <span class="reference-accessdate">
               . Retrieved
               <span class="nowrap">
                12 February
               </span>
               2012
              </span>
              .
              <q>
               Jumpman hopped over barrels, climbed ladders, and jumped from suspended platform to suspended platform as he tried to rescue a damsel from his pissed-off pet gorilla. The game was a smash, and sixty-five thousand cabinets were sold in Japan, propping up the then-struggling Nintendo and laying the groundwork for Nintendo and
               <i>
                Donkey Kong
               </i>
               creator Shigeru Miyamoto to dominate gaming throughout the 1980s and beyond.
              </q>
             </span>
             <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.au=Brian+Ashcraft+%3B+with+Jean+Snow.+%3B+forewords+by+Kevin+Williams&amp;rft.au=Crecente%2C+Brian&amp;rft.aulast=Brian+Ashcraft+%3B+with+Jean+Snow.+%3B+forewords+by+Kevin+Williams&amp;rft.btitle=Arcade+Mania%3A+The+Turbo-charged+World+of+Japan%27s+Game+Centers&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.edition=1st+ed.&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fei%3DDH03T87uGYbp8QO-rtHMAg%26id%3DwX8kAQAAIAAJ%26dq%3D%22sixty-five%2Bthousand%22&amp;rft.isbn=4-7700-3078-9&amp;rft.place=Tokyo&amp;rft.pub=Kodansha+International&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
              <span style="display:none;">
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </li>
         <li>
          United States: 67,000 of
          <i>
           Donkey Kong
          </i>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="citation web">
             Bienaim, Pierre (January 13, 2012).
             <a class="external text" href="http://www.nintendojo.com/features/columns/square-roots/square-roots-donkey-kong-nes" rel="nofollow">
              "Square Roots: Donkey Kong (NES)"
             </a>
             . Nintendojo
             <span class="reference-accessdate">
              . Retrieved
              <span class="nowrap">
               8 April
              </span>
              2012
             </span>
             .
             <q>
              Donkey Kong sold some 67,000 arcade cabinets in two years, making two of its American distributors sudden millionaires thanks to paid commission. As a barometer of success, know that Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man are the only arcade games to have sold over 100,000 units in the United States.
             </q>
            </span>
            <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.au=Bienaim%C3%A9%2C+Pierre&amp;rft.aufirst=Pierre&amp;rft.aulast=Bienaim%C3%A9&amp;rft.btitle=Square+Roots%3A+Donkey+Kong+%28NES%29&amp;rft.date=January+13%2C+2012&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nintendojo.com%2Ffeatures%2Fcolumns%2Fsquare-roots%2Fsquare-roots-donkey-kong-nes&amp;rft.pub=Nintendojo&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
             <span style="display:none;">
             </span>
            </span>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </li>
         <li>
          United States: 30,000 of
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Donkey_Kong_Jr." title="Donkey Kong Jr.">
            Donkey Kong Jr.
           </a>
          </i>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="citation" id="CITEREFSteven_L._Kent2001">
             Steven L. Kent (2001),
             <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=C2MH05ogU9oC" rel="nofollow">
              <i>
               The Ultimate History of Video Games: The Story behind the Craze that Touched Our Lives and Changed the World
              </i>
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/wiki/Prima_Games" title="Prima Games">
              Prima
             </a>
             , p.352
             <span class="reference-accessdate">
              , retrieved
              <span class="nowrap">
               2011-04-09
              </span>
             </span>
             ,
             <q>
              With more than 60,000 units sold in the United States,
              <i>
               Donkey Kong
              </i>
              was Nintendo's biggest arcade hit. The arcade industry began its long collapse the year after Donkey Kong was released, and Nintendo's arcade fortunes eroded quickly. Nintendo released
              <i>
               Donkey Kong Junior
              </i>
              in 1982 and sold only 30,000 machines, 20,000
              <i>
               Popeye
              </i>
              machines (also 1982), and a mere 5000 copies of
              <i>
               Donkey Kong 3
              </i>
              (1983).
             </q>
            </span>
            <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aulast=Steven+L.+Kent&amp;rft.au=Steven+L.+Kent&amp;rft.btitle=The+Ultimate+History+of+Video+Games%3A+The+Story+behind+the+Craze+that+Touched+Our+Lives+and+Changed+the+World&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DC2MH05ogU9oC&amp;rft.pages=352&amp;rft.pub=Prima&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
             <span style="display:none;">
             </span>
            </span>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-315">

        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation news">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.atitle=Bally+Will+Quit+Making+Pinball%2C+Video+Machines&amp;rft.date=July+11%2C+1988&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.google.com%2Fnewspapers%3Fid%3D4FtQAAAAIBAJ%26sjid%3Dkw4EAAAAIBAJ%26pg%3D6893%2C2823984&amp;rft.jtitle=Toledo+Blade&amp;rft.pages=22&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">

        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-Wolf-44-316">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-Wolf-44_316-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-Wolf-44_316-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation" id="CITEREFMark_J._P._Wolf2001">
          Mark J. P. Wolf (2001),
          <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=lKZriBxbcwQC&amp;pg=PA44" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            The medium of the video game
           </i>
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/University_of_Texas_Press" title="University of Texas Press">
           University of Texas Press
          </a>
          , p.44,
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-292-79150-X" title="Special:BookSources/0-292-79150-X">
           0-292-79150-X
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           , retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2011-04-09
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aulast=Mark+J.+P.+Wolf&amp;rft.au=Mark+J.+P.+Wolf&amp;rft.btitle=The+medium+of+the+video+game&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DlKZriBxbcwQC%26pg%3DPA44&amp;rft.isbn=0-292-79150-X&amp;rft.pages=44&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Texas+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-kent_asteroids-317">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-kent_asteroids_317-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation" id="CITEREFSteve_L._Kent2001">
          Steve L. Kent (2001),
          <i>
           The ultimate history of video games: from Pong to Pokmon and beyond: the story behind the craze that touched our lives and changed the world
          </i>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Prima_Games" title="Prima Games">
           Prima
          </a>
          , p.132,
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7615-3643-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-7615-3643-4">
           0-7615-3643-4
          </a>
          ,
          <q>
           Atari sold more than 70,000 Asteroids machines in the United States. The game did not do as well in Europe and Asia, however. Only about 30,000 units were sold overseas.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aulast=Steve+L.+Kent&amp;rft.au=Steve+L.+Kent&amp;rft.btitle=The+ultimate+history+of+video+games%3A+from+Pong+to+Pok%C3%A9mon+and+beyond+%3A+the+story+behind+the+craze+that+touched+our+lives+and+changed+the+world&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=0-7615-3643-4&amp;rft.pages=132&amp;rft.pub=Prima&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7615-3643-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-7615-3643-4">
           0-7615-3643-4
          </a>
          ,
          <q>
           In 1982, Universal Sales made arcade history with a game called Mr Do! Instead of selling dedicated Mr Do! machines, Universal sold the game as a kit. The kit came with a customized control panel, a computer board with Mr Do! read-only memory (ROM) chips, stickers that could be placed on the side of stand-up arcade machines for art, and a plastic marquee. It was the first game ever sold as a conversion only. According to former Universal Sales western regional sales manager Joe Morici, the company sold approximately 30,000 copies of the game in the United States alone.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aulast=Steve+L.+Kent&amp;rft.au=Steve+L.+Kent&amp;rft.btitle=The+ultimate+history+of+video+games%3A+from+Pong+to+Pok%C3%A9mon+and+beyond+%3A+the+story+behind+the+craze+that+touched+our+lives+and+changed+the+world&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=0-7615-3643-4&amp;rft.pages=352&amp;rft.pub=Prima&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>

        </span>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.aulast=Steve+L.+Kent&amp;rft.au=Steve+L.+Kent&amp;rft.btitle=The+ultimate+history+of+video+games%3A+from+Pong+to+Pok%C3%A9mon+and+beyond+%3A+the+story+behind+the+craze+that+touched+our+lives+and+changed+the+world&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=0-7615-3643-4&amp;rft.pages=224&amp;rft.pub=Prima&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

           With more than 60,000 units sold in the United States, Donkey Kong was Nintendo's biggest arcade hit. ... Nintendo released Donkey Kong Junior in 1982 and sold only 30,000 machines, 20,000 Popeye machines (also 1982), and a mere 5000 copies of Donkey J (1983).
          </q>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.btitle=FY2005+Third+Quarter+Financial+Results+%28April%E2%80%93December+2004%29&amp;rft.date=January+27%2C+2005&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.konami.co.jp%2Fen%2Fir%2Fpdf%2Fmeeting%2F2005%2F050127.pdf%23page%3D15&amp;rft.pages=15&amp;rft.pub=Konami&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-sega_mar09-345">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-sega_mar09_345-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.segasammy.co.jp/english/ir/library/pdf/settlement/2009/e_200903_4q_pre.pdf#page=15" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          .
          <i>
           Fiscal Year 2009: Full Year Results (Ending March 2009)
          </i>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/Sega_Sammy_Holdings" title="Sega Sammy Holdings">
           Sega Sammy Holdings
          </a>
          . May 14, 2009. p.15
          <span class="reference-accessdate">

         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.atitle=Segment+Results%3A+Amusement+Machine&amp;rft.date=May+14%2C+2009&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.segasammy.co.jp%2Fenglish%2Fir%2Flibrary%2Fpdf%2Fsettlement%2F2009%2Fe_200903_4q_pre.pdf%23page%3D15&amp;rft.jtitle=Fiscal+Year+2009%3A+Full+Year+Results+%28Ending+March+2009%29&amp;rft.pages=15&amp;rft.pub=Sega+Sammy+Holdings&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-time74-347">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-time74_347-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation" id="CITEREF1983">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,952086,00.html" rel="nofollow">
           "Business 1974: Industry: Space Age Pinball, Atari's PONG"
          </a>
          ,
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">
            Time
           </a>
          </i>
          , 1983-10-05
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           , retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2011-04-21
           </span>
          </span>
          ,
          <q>
           Typical of the new games is Pong, a popular version of electronic table tennis manufactured by two-year-old Atari, Inc. (estimated fiscal 1974 revenue: $14million) of Los Gatos, Calif. Atari sold some 8,500 games to U.S. amusement parlors and other businesses last year.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.atitle=Business+1974%3A+Industry%3A+Space+Age+Pinball%2C+Atari%27s+PONG&amp;rft.date=1983-10-05&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.time.com%2Ftime%2Fmagazine%2Farticle%2F0%2C9171%2C952086%2C00.html&amp;rft.jtitle=Time&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-ashley9-348">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-ashley9_348-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation" id="CITEREFAshley_S._Lipson_.26_Robert_D._Brain2009">
          Ashley S. Lipson &amp; Robert D. Brain (2009),
          <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IxNDAQAAIAAJ" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            Computer and Video Game Law: Cases and Materials
           </i>
          </a>
          , Carolina Academic Press, p.9,
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-59460-488-6" title="Special:BookSources/1-59460-488-6">
           1-59460-488-6
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           , retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2011-04-11
           </span>
          </span>
          ,
          <q>
           Atari eventually sold more than 19,000 Pong machines, giving rise to many imitations. Pong made its first appearance in 1972 at "Andy Capp's," a small bar in Sunnyvale, California, where the video game was literally "overplayed" as eager customers tried to cram quarters into an already heavily overloaded coin slot.
          </q>
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.au=Ashley+S.+Lipson+%26+Robert+D.+Brain&amp;rft.aulast=Ashley+S.+Lipson+%26+Robert+D.+Brain&amp;rft.btitle=Computer+and+Video+Game+Law%3A+Cases+and+Materials&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DIxNDAQAAIAAJ&amp;rft.isbn=1-59460-488-6&amp;rft.pages=9&amp;rft.pub=Carolina+Academic+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-349">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-349">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation" id="CITEREFSteven_L._Kent2000">
          Steven L. Kent (2000),
          <a class="external text" href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ny-CAAAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            The first quarter: a 25-year history of video games
           </i>
          </a>
          , BWD Press, p.83,
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-9704755-0-0" title="Special:BookSources/0-9704755-0-0">
           0-9704755-0-0
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           , retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2011-04-09
           </span>
          </span>
          ,
          <q>
           Sea Wolf, which was another creation of Dave Nutting, did solid business, selling more than 10,000 machines.
          </q>
         </span>

          .

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AList+of+best-selling+video+games&amp;rft.atitle=Diablo+3%3A+Reaper+of+Souls+shifts+2.7m+in+a+week&amp;rft.aufirst=Wesley&amp;rft.aulast=Yin-Poole&amp;rft.au=Yin-Poole%2C+Wesley&amp;rft.date=3+April+2014&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.eurogamer.net%2Farticles%2F2014-04-03-diablo-3-reaper-of-souls-shifts-2-7m-in-a-week&amp;rft.jtitle=Eurogamer&amp;rft.pub=Gamer+Network&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">

        </span>
